{}.response: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) is an independent agency of the U.S. federal government responsible for the nation's civilian space program, as well as aeronautics and aerospace research. NASA's geographical location encompasses multiple centers and facilities across the United States. Key locations include the Headquarters in Washington, D.C., which provides overall guidance and direction to the agency. The Kennedy Space Center in Florida is NASA's premier location for launch operations and human spaceflight endeavors. The Johnson Space Center in Texas serves as the hub for American human space exploration and is the home of mission control and astronaut training. The Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California conducts robotic space and Earth science missions. NASA also has additional centers and facilities, such as the Marshall Space Flight Center in Alabama, which specializes in spacecraft propulsion and engineering. Moreover, NASA operates the Ames Research Center in California focusing on research and technology development and the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland, dedicated to the study of Earth and space sciences. These locations collectively support NASA's wide array of research, exploration, and technological development missions.
